results.title: Who dares wins: men of the Special Air Service Regiment
results.brief_description: The title of this film is the motto of the Special Air Service Regiment, or SAS as it is commonly known. These men of the Australian Army possess specialist skills which are utilised, together with further training, to mould an elite fighting force. Shows their primary role in reconnaissance, surveillance and harassment of an enemy.

results.title: Who cares about Jamie?
results.brief_description: Discusses the problem of metal health and suggests prevention as a solution. Follows James through a few hours of his young life and then analyses the reaction of adults involved. Stresses the role adults, particularly partner and teachers play: a child needs understanding at every stage of development if he is to acquire the capacity to face life.

results.title: Who's responsible?
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande and JW Newman Corp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
I am the cause of my own effects. This is a difficult concept for many to accept; most people prefer to “blame” others or environment for what happens to them. Teenagers attending a PACE conference deal with the concept of responsibility. Their discussions highlight how ‘what happens to you is under your own control to a very great extent’ and that, by exercising your choice, you can ‘create the effect your want to have in your life’.

results.title: Putting yourself together
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Two teenagers and counsellor Daniel Whiteside take a close look at how to think your way past the put-downs or problems that often weaken your self-image. The give-and-take between the three, draws us into the film and challenges us all to start taking control of this part of our lives.

results.title: Kids, parents and pressures
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande, Bailey Film Productions and Robert Sande Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Teenagers attending a PACE Seminar identify some of the everyday pressures and tensions that confront them. With the help of highly qualified instructors, they learn they are in control of their own attitudes and work out positive and effective ways of improving their attitudes and relieving pressures.

results.title: White flood
results.brief_description: The film opens with a review of the forces that affect the surface of the earth - volcanic action, earthquakes, atmospheric conditions. A study of glaciers follows in which the life history of a glacier is examined from its birthplace in the mountains to the day when it floats into the sea.

results.title: White blood cells: defense against disease
results.brief_description: Shows how the white blood cells capture the diseased organisms and destroy them. Special cells not only destroy bacteria, but are also capable of removing white blood cells that have been overcome in their battle with the invading organisms. Removal of invading organisms prevents them from multiplying and overwhelming the body defences. Shows the white blood cells in all the various work they do.

results.title: White Australia Policy
results.creator_credit: Student Action of Melbourne University and Unifed Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary record culled from television and other news reports on the White Australia Policy as it found expression in topical incidents in 1961, 1962 and 1963. It is a protest against the White Australia Policy and a record of the events in the history of Student Action. Compiled and edited by Peter Tammer. Dedicated to the memory of Bill Thomas, student leader.
